title: History of terrorism
text:
The history of terrorism is a history of well-known and historically significant individuals, entities, and incidents associated, whether rightly or wrongly, with <a href="terrorism">terrorism</a>. Scholars agree that terrorism is a <a href="definition%20of%20terrorism">disputed term</a>, and very few of those labeled terrorists describe themselves as such. It is common for opponents in a violent conflict to describe the other side as terrorists or as practicing terrorism.
Depending on how broadly the term is defined, the roots and practice of terrorism can be traced at least to the 1st-century AD <a href="Sicarii%20Zealots">Sicarii Zealots</a>, though some dispute whether the group, which <a href="assassination">assassinated</a> collaborators with Roman rule in the province of <a href="Judea">Judea</a>, was in fact terrorist. The first use in English of the term 'terrorism' occurred during the <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a>'s <a href="Reign%20of%20Terror">Reign of Terror</a>, when the <a href="Jacobins">Jacobins</a>, who ruled the revolutionary state, employed violence, including mass executions by guillotine, to compel obedience to the state and intimidate regime enemies. The association of the term only with state violence and intimidation lasted until the mid-19th century, when it began to be associated with non-governmental groups. <a href="Anarchism">Anarchism</a>, often in league with rising <a href="nationalism">nationalism</a> and <a href="anti-monarchism">anti-monarchism</a>, was the most prominent ideology linked with terrorism. Near the end of the 19th century, anarchist groups or individuals committed assassinations of a Russian Tsar and a U.S. President.
In the 20th century, terrorism continued to be associated with a vast array of anarchist, socialist, fascist and nationalist groups, many of them engaged in '<a href="third%20world">third world</a>' independence struggles. Some scholars also labeled as terrorist the systematic internal violence and intimidation practiced by states such as the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union%20%281927%E2%80%9353%29">Stalinist Soviet Union</a> and <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>.
Definition.
Though many have been proposed, there is no consensus definition of the term "terrorism." This in part derives from the fact that the term is politically and emotionally charged, "a word with intrinsically negative connotations that is generally applied to one's enemies and opponents."
The term terrorist is believed to have originated during the <a href="Reign%20of%20Terror">Reign of Terror</a> (September 5, 1793July 28, 1794) in France. It was a period of eleven months during the <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a> when the ruling <a href="Jacobin%20%28politics%29">Jacobins</a> employed violence, including mass executions by <a href="guillotine">guillotine</a>, in order to intimidate the regime's enemies and compel obedience to the state. The Jacobins, most famously <a href="Maximilien%20Robespierre">Robespierre</a>, sometimes referred to themselves as "terrorists". Some modern scholars, however, do not consider the Reign of Terror a form of terrorism, in part because it was carried out by the French state. French historian distinguishes between the <a href="revolutionary%20terror">revolutionary terror</a> of the French Revolution and the terrorists of the September 11 attacks:
Revolutionary terror is not terrorism. To make a moral equivalence between the Revolution's year II and September 2001 is historical and philosophical nonsense ... The violence exercised on 11 September 2001 aimed neither at equality nor liberty. Nor did the preventive war announced by the president of the United States. 
Early terrorism.
Scholars dispute whether the roots of terrorism date back to the 1st century and the <a href="Sicarii%20Zealots">Sicarii Zealots</a>, to the 11th century and the <a href="Hashshashin">Hashshashin</a>, to the 19th century and the <a href="Fenian%20Brotherhood">Fenian Brotherhood</a> and <a href="Narodnaya%20Volya%20%28organization%29">Narodnaya Volya</a>, or to other eras. The Sicarii and the Hashshashin are described below, while the Fenian Brotherhood and Narodnaya Volya are discussed in the 19th Century sub-section. Other pre-Reign of Terror historical events sometimes associated with terrorism include the <a href="Gunpowder%20Plot">Gunpowder Plot</a>, an attempt to destroy the English <a href="Palace%20of%20Westminster">Parliament</a> in 1605.
During the 1st century CE, the <a href="Zealotry">Jewish Zealots</a> in <a href="Judaea%20Province">Judaea Province</a> rebelled, killing prominent collaborators with Roman rule. In 6 CE, according to contemporary historian <a href="Josephus">Josephus</a>, <a href="Judas%20of%20Galilee">Judas of Galilee</a> formed a small and more extreme offshoot of the Zealots, the <a href="Sicarii">Sicarii</a> ("dagger men"). Their efforts were also directed against Jewish "collaborators," including temple priests, <a href="Sadducees">Sadducees</a>, <a href="Herodians">Herodians</a>, and other wealthy elites. According to Josephus, the Sicarii would hide short daggers under their cloaks, mingle with crowds at large festivals, murder their victims, and then disappear into the panicked crowds. Their most successful assassination was of the <a href="List%20of%20High%20Priests%20of%20Israel">High Priest of Israel</a> Jonathan.
In the late 11th century, the <a href="Hashshashin">Hashshashin</a> (a.k.a. the Assassins) arose, an offshoot of the <a href="Isma%27ili">Isma'ili</a> sect of <a href="Shia">Shia</a> <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a>s. Led by <a href="Hassan-i%20Sabbah">Hassan-i Sabbah</a> and opposed to <a href="Fatimid%20Caliphate">Fatimid</a> and <a href="Seljuq%20Empire">Seljuq</a> rule, the Hashshashin militia seized <a href="Alamut%20Castle">Alamut</a> and other <a href="List%20of%20Ismaili%20castles">fortress strongholds</a> across Persia. Hashshashin forces were too small to challenge enemies militarily, so they assassinated city governors and military commanders in order to create alliances with militarily powerful neighbors. For example, they killed Janah al-Dawla, ruler of <a href="Homs">Homs</a>, to please <a href="Ridwan%20of%20Aleppo">Ridwan of Aleppo</a>, and assassinated <a href="Mawdud">Mawdud</a>, <a href="Seljuq%20dynasty">Seljuk</a> emir of <a href="Mosul">Mosul</a>, as a favor to the regent of <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a>. The Hashshashin also carried out assassinations as retribution. Under some definitions of terrorism, such <a href="assassinations">assassinations</a> do not qualify as terrorism, since killing a political leader does not intimidate political enemies or inspire revolt. "(see also <a href="List%20of%20assassinations%20by%20the%20Assassins">List of assassinations by the Assassins</a>)"
The <a href="Sons%20of%20Liberty">Sons of Liberty</a> was a clandestine group that formed in <a href="Boston">Boston</a> and <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> in the 1770s. It had a political agenda of independence of Britain's American colonies. The groups engaged in several acts that could be considered terroristic and used the deeds for propaganda purposes.
Gunpowder Plot.
On November 5, 1605, a group of conspirators led by <a href="Robert%20Catesby">Robert Catesby</a> attempted to destroy the English Parliament on its State Opening by King James I. They planned in secret to detonate a large quantity of <a href="gunpowder">gunpowder</a> placed beneath the <a href="Palace%20of%20Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>. The gunpowder was procured and placed by <a href="Guy%20Fawkes">Guy Fawkes</a>. The group intended to enact a coup by killing King James I and the members of both houses of Parliament. The conspirators planned to make one of the king's children a puppet monarch and then restore the Catholic faith to England. The conspirator leased a coal cellar beneath the House of Lords and began stockpiling gunpowder in 1604. As well as its primary targets, it would have killed hundreds, if not thousands, of Londoners – the most devastating act of terrorism in Britain's history, plunging the nation into a religious war. English spymasters uncovered the plot and caught Guy Fawkes with the gunpowder beneath Parliament. The other conspirators fled to Holbeach in Staffordshire. A shoot out on November 8 with authorities led to the deaths of Robert Catesby, Thomas Percy and the brothers Christopher and John Wright. The rest were captured. Fawkes and seven others were tried and executed in January 1606. The planned attack has become known as the Gunpowder Plot and is commemorated in Britain every November 5 with fireworks displays and large bonfires with effigies of Guy Fawkes and <a href="the%20Pope">the Pope</a> are often burned. Comparisons are often drawn between gunpowder plot and modern religious terrorism, such as the attacks in the US by Islamic terrorists on <a href="9/11">9/11</a> 2001.
Emergence of modern terrorism.
Terrorism was associated with <a href="state%20terror">state terror</a> and the <a href="Reign%20of%20Terror">Reign of Terror</a> in France, until the mid-19th century when the term also began to be associated with non-governmental groups. <a href="Anarchism">Anarchism</a>, often in league with rising <a href="nationalism">nationalism</a>, was the most prominent ideology linked with terrorism. Attacks by various anarchist groups led to the assassination of a Russian <a href="Tsar">Tsar</a> and a <a href="William%20McKinley%20assassination">U.S. President</a>.
In the 19th century, powerful, stable, and affordable explosives were developed, global integration reached unprecedented levels and often radical political movements became widely influential. The use of <a href="dynamite">dynamite</a>, in particular, inspired anarchists and was central to their strategic thinking.
Ireland.
One of the earliest groups to utilize modern terrorist techniques was arguably the <a href="Fenian%20Brotherhood">Fenian Brotherhood</a> and its offshoot the <a href="Irish%20Republican%20Brotherhood">Irish Republican Brotherhood</a>. They were both founded in 1858 as revolutionary, militant nationalist and Catholic groups, both in Ireland and amongst the emigre community in the United States.
After centuries of continued British rule, and being influenced most recently from the devastating effects of the 1840s <a href="Great%20Famine%20%28Ireland%29">Great Famine</a>, these revolutionary fraternal organisations were founded with the aim of establishing an independent republic in Ireland, and began carrying out frequent acts of violence in metropolitan Britain to achieve their aims through intimidation.
In 1867, members of the movement's leadership were arrested and convicted for organizing an <a href="Fenian%20Rising">armed uprising</a>. While being transferred to <a href="Belle%20Vue%20Gaol">prison</a>, the police van in which they were being transported was intercepted and a <a href="police">police</a> sergeant was shot in the rescue. A bolder rescue attempt of another Irish radical incarcerated in <a href="Clerkenwell%20Prison">Clerkenwell Prison</a>, was made in the same year: an explosion to demolish the prison wall killed 12 people and caused many injuries. The bombing enraged the British public, causing a panic over the Fenian threat.
Although the Irish Republican Brotherhood condemned the Clerkenwell Outrage as a "dreadful and deplorable event", the organisation returned to bombings in Britain in 1881 to 1885, with the <a href="Fenian%20dynamite%20campaign">Fenian dynamite campaign</a>, beginning one of the first modern terror campaigns. Instead of earlier forms of terrorism based on political assassination, this campaign used modern, timed explosives with the express aim of sowing fear in the very heart of metropolitan Britain, in order to achieve political gains. (<a href="Prime%20minister">Prime minister</a> <a href="William%20Ewart%20Gladstone">William Ewart Gladstone</a> was partly influenced to disestablish the <a href="Anglican%20Church%20in%20Ireland">Anglican Church in Ireland</a> as a gesture by the Clerkenwell bombing.) The campaign also took advantage of the greater global integration of the times, and the bombing was largely funded and organised by the <a href="Fenian%20Brotherhood">Fenian Brotherhood</a> in the United States.
The first police unit to combat terrorism was established in 1883 by the <a href="Metropolitan%20Police">Metropolitan Police</a>, initially as a small section of the <a href="Criminal%20Investigation%20Department">Criminal Investigation Department</a>. It was known as the <a href="Special%20Irish%20Branch">Special Irish Branch</a>, and was trained in counter terrorism techniques to combat the Irish Republican Brotherhood. The unit's name was changed to Special Branch as the unit's remit steadily widened over the years.
Russia.
The concept of "<a href="propaganda%20of%20the%20deed">propaganda of the deed</a>" (or "propaganda by the deed", from the French "propagande par le fait") advocated physical <a href="violence">violence</a> or other provocative public acts against political enemies in order to inspire mass rebellion or <a href="revolution">revolution</a>. One of the first individuals associated with this concept, the Italian revolutionary <a href="Carlo%20Pisacane">Carlo Pisacane</a> (18181857), wrote in his "Political Testament" (1857) that "ideas spring from deeds and not the other way around". <a href="Anarchist">Anarchist</a> <a href="Mikhail%20Bakunin">Mikhail Bakunin</a> (18141876), in his "Letters to a Frenchman on the Present Crisis" (1870) stated that "we must spread our principles, not with words but with deeds, for this is the most popular, the most potent, and the most irresistible form of propaganda". The French <a href="anarchist">anarchist</a> <a href="Paul%20Brousse">Paul Brousse</a> (18441912) popularized the phrase "propaganda of the deed"; in 1877 he cited as examples the 1871 <a href="Paris%20Commune">Paris Commune</a> and a workers' demonstration in <a href="Berne">Berne</a> provocatively using the socialist red flag. By the 1880s, the slogan had begun to be used to refer to bombings, <a href="regicide">regicide</a>s and <a href="tyrannicide">tyrannicide</a>s. Reflecting this new understanding of the term, in 1895 Italian anarchist <a href="Errico%20Malatesta">Errico Malatesta</a> described "propaganda by the deed" (which he opposed the use of) as violent communal insurrections meant to ignite an imminent revolution.
Founded in Russia in 1878, <a href="Narodnaya%20Volya%20%28organization%29">Narodnaya Volya</a> ("Народная Воля" in Russian; "People's Will" in English) was a revolutionary anarchist group inspired by <a href="Sergei%20Nechayev">Sergei Nechayev</a> and by "propaganda by the deed" theorist Pisacane. The group developed ideas—such as <a href="targeted%20killing">targeted killing</a> of the "leaders of oppression"—that would become the hallmark of subsequent violence by small non-state groups, and they were convinced that the developing technologies of the age—such as the invention of dynamite, which they were the first anarchist group to make widespread use of—enabled them to strike directly and with discrimination. Attempting to spark a popular revolt against Russian Tsardom, the group killed prominent political figures by gun and bomb, and on March 13, 1881, assassinated Russia's Tsar <a href="Alexander%20II%20of%20Russia">Alexander II</a>. The assassination, by a bomb that also killed the Tsar's attacker, <a href="Ignacy%20Hryniewiecki">Ignacy Hryniewiecki</a>, failed to spark the expected revolution, and an ensuing crackdown brought the group to an end.
Individual Europeans also engaged in politically motivated violence. For example, in 1893, <a href="Auguste%20Vaillant">Auguste Vaillant</a>, a French <a href="Anarchism">anarchist</a>, threw a bomb in the French <a href="Chamber%20of%20Deputies">Chamber of Deputies</a> in which one person was injured. In reaction to Vaillant's bombing and other bombings and assassination attempts, the French government restricted <a href="freedom%20of%20the%20press">freedom of the press</a> by passing a set of <a href="law">law</a>s that became pejoratively known as the "<a href="lois%20sc%C3%A9l%C3%A9rates">lois scélérates</a>" ("villainous laws"). In the years 1894 to 1896 anarchists killed President of France <a href="Marie%20Francois%20Carnot">Marie Francois Carnot</a>, Prime Minister of Spain <a href="Antonio%20C%C3%A1novas%20del%20Castillo">Antonio Cánovas del Castillo</a>, and the Empress of Austria-Hungary, <a href="Elisabeth%20of%20Bavaria">Elisabeth of Bavaria</a>.
The United States.
Prior to the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, <a href="abolitionism">abolitionist</a> <a href="John%20Brown%20%28abolitionist%29">John Brown</a> (18001859) advocated and practiced armed opposition to <a href="slavery">slavery</a>, leading several attacks between 1856 and 1859, the most famous attack was launched in 1859 against the <a href="Harpers%20Ferry%20Armory">armory</a> at <a href="Harpers%20Ferry%2C%20West%20Virginia">Harpers Ferry</a>. Local forces soon recaptured the fort and Brown was tried and executed for <a href="treason">treason</a>. A biographer of Brown has written that Brown's purpose was "to force the nation into a new political pattern by creating terror." In 2009, the 150th anniversary of Brown's death, prominent news publications debated over whether or not Brown should be considered a terrorist.
After the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a>, on December 24, 1865, six <a href="Confederate%20States%20of%20America">Confederate</a> veterans created the <a href="Ku%20Klux%20Klan">Ku Klux Klan</a> (KKK). The KKK used violence, lynching, murder and acts of intimidation such as <a href="cross%20burning">cross burning</a> to oppress <a href="African%20Americans">African Americans</a> in particular, and it created a sensation with its masked forays' dramatic nature. The group's politics were <a href="white%20supremacy">white supremacist</a>, <a href="anti-Semitism">anti-Semitic</a>, <a href="racism">racist</a>, <a href="anti-Catholicism">anti-Catholic</a>, and <a href="Nativism%20%28politics%29">nativist</a>. A KKK founder boasted that it was a nationwide organization of 550,000 men and that it could muster 40,000 Klansmen within five days' notice, but as a secret or "<a href="Invisible%20dictatorship">invisible</a>" group with no membership rosters, it was difficult to judge the Klan's actual size. The KKK has at times been politically powerful, and at various times it controlled the governments of <a href="Tennessee">Tennessee</a>, <a href="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a>, <a href="Indiana">Indiana</a> and <a href="South%20Carolina">South Carolina</a>, as well as several legislatures in <a href="Southern%20United%20States">the South</a>.
The Ottoman Empire.
Several nationalist groups used violence against an <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> in apparent decline. One was the <a href="Armenian%20Revolutionary%20Federation">Armenian Revolutionary Federation</a> (in Armenian "Dashnaktsuthium", or "The Federation"), a revolutionary movement founded in <a href="Tiflis">Tiflis</a> (Russian Transcaucasia) in 1890 by <a href="Christapor%20Mikaelian">Christapor Mikaelian</a>. Many members had been part of <a href="Narodnaya%20Volya%20%28organization%29">Narodnaya Volya</a> or the <a href="Hunchakian%20Revolutionary%20Party">Hunchakian Revolutionary Party</a>. The group published newsletters, smuggled arms, and hijacked buildings as it sought to bring in European intervention that would force the Ottoman Empire to surrender control of its Armenian territories. On August 24, 1896, 17-year-old Babken Suni led twenty-six members in <a href="1896%20Ottoman%20Bank%20Takeover">capturing the Imperial Ottoman Bank in Constantinople</a>. The group demanded European intervention in order to stop the <a href="Hamidian%20massacres">Hamidian massacres</a> and the creation of an Armenian state, but backed down on a threat to blow up the bank. An ensuing security crackdown destroyed the group.
Also inspired by Narodnaya Volya, the <a href="Internal%20Macedonian%20Revolutionary%20Organization">Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization</a> (IMRO) was a revolutionary movement founded in 1893 by Hristo Tatarchev in the Ottoman-controlled Macedonian territories. Through assassinations and by provoking uprisings, the group sought to coerce the Ottoman government into creating a Macedonian nation. On July 20, 1903, the group incited the Ilinden uprising in the Ottoman villayet of Monastir. The IMRO declared the town's independence and sent demands to the <a href="European%20Powers">European Powers</a> that all of Macedonia be freed. The demands were ignored and Turkish troops crushed the 27,000 rebels in the town two months later.
Early 20th century.
Revolutionary nationalism continued to motivate political violence in the 20th century, much of it directed against Western powers. The <a href="Irish%20Republican%20Army">Irish Republican Army</a> campaigned against the British in the 1910s and their tactics inspired Zionist groups such as the <a href="Hagannah">Hagannah</a>, <a href="Irgun">Irgun</a> and <a href="Lehi%20%28group%29">Lehi</a> to in their guerilla war against the <a href="Mandatory%20Palestine">Palestine Mandate</a> throughout the 1930s. Like the IRA and the Zionist groups, the <a href="Muslim%20Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a> in Egypt used bombings and assassinations as part of their tactics.
The women's <a href="suffrage%20movement">suffrage movement</a> in the UK also committed acts of violence prior to the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> although whether constituted terrorism is a controversial issue. There were three phases of <a href="Women%27s%20Social%20and%20Political%20Union">WSPU</a> militancy in 1905, 1908, and, most significantly, between 1912 and 1914. These action ranged from civil disobedience and destruction of public property to arson and bombings. Most notably, The WSPU bombed Government Minister and future Prime Minister <a href="David%20Lloyd%20George">David Lloyd George</a>'s house
Political assassinations continued, resulting in the assassinations of King <a href="Umberto%20I%20of%20Italy">Umberto I of Italy</a>, killed in July 1900 and US President <a href="William%20McKinley">William McKinley</a> in September 1901. Political violence became especially widespread in <a href="Imperial%20Russia">Imperial Russia</a>, and several ministers were killed in the opening years of the 20th century. The highest-ranking was prime minister <a href="Pyotr%20Stolypin">Pyotr Stolypin</a>, killed in 1911 by Dmitry Bogrov, a spy for the secret police in several anarchist, socialist and other revolutionary groups.
On June 28, 1914, <a href="Gavrilo%20Princip">Gavrilo Princip</a>, one of a group of six assassins, shot and killed <a href="Archduke%20Franz%20Ferdinand%20of%20Austria">Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria</a>, heir to the <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian</a> throne, and his wife, <a href="Sophie%2C%20Duchess%20of%20Hohenberg">Sophie, Duchess of Hohenberg</a>, in <a href="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a>, the capital of the Condominion of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The assassinations produced widespread shock across Europe, setting in motion a series of events which led to <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>.
In the 1930s, the <a href="Nazi">Nazi</a> regime in Germany and <a href="Stalin">Stalin</a>'s rule in <a href="the%20Soviet%20Union">the Soviet Union</a> practiced <a href="state%20terror">state terror</a> systematically and on a massive and unprecedented scale. Meanwhile, the Stalin regime branded its opponents with the label "terrorist".
Irish independence.
In an action called the <a href="Easter%20Rising">Easter Rising</a> or <a href="Easter%20Rebellion">Easter Rebellion</a>, on April 24, 1916, members of the <a href="Irish%20Volunteers">Irish Volunteers</a> and the <a href="Irish%20Citizen%20Army">Irish Citizen Army</a> seized the <a href="General%20Post%20Office%20%28Dublin%29">Dublin General Post Office</a> and several other buildings, proclaiming an independent Irish Republic. The rebellion failed militarily but was a success for <a href="physical%20force%20Irish%20republicanism">physical force Irish republicanism</a>, leaders of the uprising becoming heroes in Ireland after their eventual sentence of capital punishment by the British government.
Shortly after the rebellion, <a href="Michael%20Collins%20%28Irish%20leader%29">Michael Collins</a> and others founded the <a href="Irish%20Republican%20Army">Irish Republican Army</a> (IRA), which from 1916 to 1923 carried out numerous attacks against the British authorities. For example, it attacked over 300 police stations simultaneously just before Easter 1920, and, in November 1920, publicly killed a dozen police officers and burned down the Liverpool docks and warehouses, an action that became known as <a href="Bloody%20Sunday%20%281920%29">Bloody Sunday</a>.
After years of warfare, London agreed to the 1921 Anglo-Irish treaty creating a free Irish state encompassing 26 of the island's 32 counties. IRA tactics were an inspiration to other groups, including the <a href="Mandatory%20Palestine">Palestine Mandate</a>'s <a href="Zionism">Zionists</a>, and to <a href="Special%20Operations%20Executive">British special operations</a> during World War II.
The IRA are considered by some the innovators of modern insurgency tactics as the British would replicate and build upon the tactics used against them in World War II against the Germans and Italians. <a href="Tony%20Geraghty">Tony Geraghty</a> in "The Irish War: The Hidden Conflict Between the IRA and British Intelligence" wrote:
From January 1939 to March 1940, the <a href="Irish%20Republican%20Army%20%281922-1969%29">Irish Republican Army</a> (IRA) carried out a campaign of bombing and <a href="sabotage">sabotage</a> against the civil, economic, and military infrastructure of Britain. It was known as the <a href="S-Plan">S-Plan or Sabotage Campaign</a>. During the campaign, the IRA carried out almost 300 attacks and acts of sabotage in Britain, killing seven people and injuring 96. Most of the casualties occurred in the <a href="1939%20Coventry%20bombing">Coventry bombing</a> on 25 August 1939.
Mandatory Palestine.
Following the <a href="1929%20Hebron%20massacre">1929 Hebron massacre</a> of 67 Jews in the <a href="Mandatory%20Palestine">Mandate of Palestine</a>, the <a href="Zionism">Zionist</a> militia <a href="Haganah">Haganah</a> transformed itself into a paramilitary force. In 1931, however, the more militant <a href="Irgun">Irgun</a> broke away from Haganah, objecting to Haganah's policy of <a href="Havlagah">restraint</a>. Founded by <a href="Avraham%20Tehomi">Avraham Tehomi</a>, Irgun sought to aggressively defend Jews from Arab attacks. Its tactic of attacking Arab communities, including the bombing of a crowded Arab market, is considered among the first examples of terrorism directed against civilians. After the British published the <a href="White%20Paper%20of%201939">White Paper of 1939</a>, which placed strict restrictions on Jewish immigration into Palestine (which was seen as unacceptable to Zionist groups), the Irgun began a campaign against the British authorities by assassinating police, capturing British government buildings and arms, and sabotaging railways. Irgun's best-known attack targeted the <a href="King%20David%20Hotel%20bombing">King David Hotel</a> in Jerusalem, parts of which housed the headquarters of the British civil and military administrations. The bombing, in 1946, killed ninety-one people and injured forty-six, making it the most deadly attack during the Mandate era. This attack was sharply condemned by the organized leadership of the Yishuv, and further widened the gulf between <a href="David%20Ben-Gurion">David Ben-Gurion</a>'s <a href="Hagana">Hagana</a> and Begin's Irgun. Following the bombing, Ben-Gurion called Irgun an "enemy of the Jewish people". After the founding of the state of Israel in 1948, Menachem Begin (Irgun leader from 1943 to 1948) transformed the group into the political party <a href="Herut">Herut</a>, which later became part of <a href="Likud">Likud</a> in an alliance with the center-right <a href="Gahal">Gahal</a>, <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28Israel%29">Liberal Party</a>, <a href="Free%20Centre">Free Centre</a>, <a href="National%20List">National List</a>, and <a href="Movement%20for%20Greater%20Israel">Movement for Greater Israel</a>. On the 60th anniversary of the bombing, a plaque was unveiled at the hotel.
Operating in the <a href="Mandatory%20Palestine">Palestine Mandate</a> in the 1930s, <a href="Izz%20ad-Din%20al-Qassam">Izz ad-Din al-Qassam</a> (1882–1935) organized and established the <a href="Black%20Hand%20%28Palestine%29">Black Hand</a>, a Palestinian nationalist militia. He recruited and arranged military training for <a href="peasant">peasant</a>s, and by 1935 had enlisted between 200 and 800 men. Al-Qassam obtained a <a href="fatwa">fatwa</a> from Shaykh Badr al-Din al-Taji al-Hasani, the <a href="Mufti">Mufti</a> of <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a>, authorizing an armed insurgency against the British and against the Jews of Palestine. Black Hand cells were equipped with bombs and firearms, which they used to kill Jews. Although al-Qassam's revolt was unsuccessful in his lifetime, many organizations gained inspiration from his example. He became a popular hero and an inspiration to subsequent Arab militants, who in the <a href="1936%E2%80%9339%20Arab%20revolt%20in%20Palestine">193639 Arab revolt</a>, called themselves Qassamiyun, followers of al-Qassam. The <a href="Izz%20ad-Din%20al-Qassam%20Brigades">Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades</a>, the military wing of <a href="Hamas">Hamas</a>, as well as the <a href="Qassam%20rocket">rockets</a> they developed, take their names after Qassam.
<a href="Lehi%20%28group%29">Lehi</a> ("Lohamei Herut Yisrael", a.k.a. "Freedom Fighters for Israel", a.k.a. the Stern Gang) was a <a href="Revisionist%20Zionism">revisionist Zionist</a> group that splintered off from <a href="Irgun">Irgun</a> in 1940. <a href="Abraham%20Stern">Abraham Stern</a> formed Lehi from disaffected Irgun members after Irgun agreed to a truce with Britain in 1940. Lehi assassinated prominent politicians as a strategy. For example, on November 6, 1944, <a href="Lord%20Moyne">Lord Moyne</a>, the British Minister of State for the Middle East, was assassinated. The act was controversial among Zionist militant groups, <a href="Hagannah">Hagannah</a> sympathizing with the British in this instance and launching <a href="the%20Hunting%20Season">a massive man-hunt</a> against members of Lehi and Irgun. After Israel's 1948 founding, Lehi formally dissolved and its members became integrated into the <a href="Israeli%20Defense%20Forces">Israeli Defense Forces</a>.
Resistance during WWII.
Some of the tactics of the <a href="Resistance%20during%20World%20War%20II">guerrilla, partisan, and resistance movements</a> organised and supplied by the <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">Allies</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, according to historian M. R. D. Foot, can be considered terrorist. <a href="Colin%20Gubbins">Colin Gubbins</a>, a key leader within the <a href="Special%20Operations%20Executive">Special Operations Executive</a> (SOE), made sure the organization drew much of its inspiration from the IRA.
On the eve of <a href="Normandy%20landings">D-Day</a>, the <a href="Special%20Operations%20Executive">SOE</a> organised with the <a href="French%20Resistance">French Resistance</a> the complete destruction of the rail and communication infrastructure of western France the largest coordinated attack of its kind in history Allied supreme commander <a href="Dwight%20Eisenhower">Dwight Eisenhower</a> later wrote that "the disruption of enemy rail communications, the harassing of German road moves and the continual and increasing strain placed on German security services throughout occupied Europe by the organised forces of Resistance, played a very considerable part in our complete and final victory". The SOE also conducted operations in Africa, the Middle East and the Far East.

Communism, Nationalism, Independence struggles and Cold War proxies.
After World War II, largely successful campaigns for independence were launched against the collapsing European empires, as many World War II resistance groups became militantly <a href="Nationalism">nationalistic</a>. The <a href="Viet%20Minh">Viet Minh</a>, for example, which had fought against the Japanese, now fought against the returning <a href="First%20Indochina%20War">French</a> colonists. In the Middle East, the <a href="Muslim%20Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a> used bombings and assassinations against the British in Egypt. Also during the 1950s, the <a href="National%20Liberation%20Front%20%28Algeria%29">National Liberation Front</a> (FLN) in French-controlled Algeria and the <a href="EOKA">EOKA</a> in British-controlled Cyprus waged <a href="guerrilla">guerrilla</a> and open war against the authorities.
In the 1960s, inspired by <a href="Mao%20Zedong">Mao's</a> Chinese revolution of 1949 and <a href="Fidel%20Castro">Castro's</a> <a href="Cuban%20revolution">Cuban revolution</a> of 1959, national independence movements often fused nationalist and <a href="socialism">socialist</a> impulses. This was the case with Spain's <a href="ETA%20%28separatist%20group%29">ETA</a>, the <a href="Front%20de%20lib%C3%A9ration%20du%20Qu%C3%A9bec">Front de libération du Québec</a>, and the <a href="Palestine%20Liberation%20Organization">Palestine Liberation Organization</a>.
In the late 1960s and 1970s violent <a href="left-wing%20politics">left wing</a> and revolutionary groups were on the rise, sympathizing with <a href="Third%20World">Third World</a> guerrilla movements and seeking to spark anti-capitalist revolts. Such groups included the <a href="Kurdistan%20Workers%27%20Party">PKK</a> in Turkey, Armenia's <a href="ASALA">ASALA</a>, the <a href="Japanese%20Red%20Army">Japanese Red Army</a>, the <a href="German%20Red%20Army%20Faction">German Red Army Faction</a>, the <a href="Montoneros">Montoneros</a>, the <a href="Italian%20Red%20Brigades">Italian Red Brigades</a>, and, in the United States, the <a href="Weather%20Underground">Weather Underground</a>. Nationalist groups such as the <a href="Provisional%20Irish%20Republican%20Army">Provisional IRA</a> and the <a href="Tamil%20tigers">Tamil tigers</a> also began operations at this time.
Throughout the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a>, both the United States and the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> made extensive use of violent nationalist organizations to carry on a war by proxy. For example, Soviet and Chinese military advisers provided training and support to the <a href="Viet%20Cong">Viet Cong</a> during the <a href="Vietnam%20War">Vietnam War</a>. The Soviet Union also provided military support to the <a href="PLO">PLO</a> during the <a href="Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian%20conflict">Israeli–Palestinian conflict</a>, and <a href="Fidel%20Castro">Fidel Castro</a> during the <a href="Cuban%20Revolution">Cuban Revolution</a>. The United States funded groups such as the <a href="Contras">Contras</a> in Nicaragua. The <a href="Mujahadeen">Mujahadeen</a> of the late 20th and early 21st century had been funded in the 1980s by the United States and other Western powers because they were fighting the USSR in Afghanistan.
Middle East.
Founded in 1928 as a nationalist social-welfare and political movement in Egypt, the <a href="Muslim%20Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a> began to attack British soldiers and police stations in the late 1940s. Founded and led by <a href="Hassan%20al-Banna">Hassan al-Banna</a>, it also assassinated politicians seen as collaborating with British rule, most prominently Egyptian Prime Minister <a href="Mahmoud%20El%20Nokrashy%20Pasha">Nuqrashi</a> in 1948. In 1952 a military coup overthrew British rule, and shortly thereafter the Muslim Brotherhood went underground in the face of a massive crackdown. Though sometimes banned or otherwise oppressed by the <a href="Government%20of%20Egypt">Egyptian government</a>, the group continues to exist in present-day Egypt.
The <a href="National%20Liberation%20Front%20%28Algeria%29">National Liberation Front</a> (FLN) was a nationalist group founded in French-controlled Algeria in 1954. The group became a large-scale resistance movement against French rule, with terrorism only part of its operations. The FLN leadership took inspiration from the <a href="Viet%20Minh">Viet Minh</a> rebels who had made French troops withdraw from Vietnam. The FLN was one of the first anti-colonial groups to use large-scale compliance violence. The FLN would establish control over a rural village and coerce its peasants to execute any French loyalists among them. On the night of October 31, 1954, in a coordinated wave of seventy bombings and shootings known as the <a href="Toussaint%20attacks">Toussaint attacks</a>, the FLN attacked French military installations and the homes of Algerian loyalists. In the following year, the group gained significant support for an uprising against loyalists in <a href="Philippeville">Philippeville</a>. This uprising, and the heavy-handed response by the French, convinced many Algerians to support the FLN and the independence movement. The FLN eventually secured Algerian independence from France in 1962, and transformed itself into Algeria's ruling party.
<a href="Fatah">Fatah</a> was organized as a Palestinian nationalist group in 1954, and exists today as a political party in <a href="Palestine%20%28region%29">Palestine</a>. In 1967 it joined the <a href="Palestine%20Liberation%20Organization">Palestine Liberation Organization</a> (PLO), an umbrella organization for secular Palestinian nationalist groups formed in 1964. The PLO began its own armed operations in 1965. The PLO's membership comprises separate and possibly contending paramilitary and political factions, the largest of which include <a href="Fatah">Fatah</a>, the <a href="Popular%20Front%20for%20the%20Liberation%20of%20Palestine">Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine</a> (PFLP), and the <a href="Democratic%20Front%20for%20the%20Liberation%20of%20Palestine">Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine</a> (DFLP). Factions of the PLO have advocated or carried out acts of terrorism. <a href="Abu%20Iyad">Abu Iyad</a> organized the Fatah splinter group <a href="Black%20September%20%28group%29">Black September</a> in 1970; the group is arguably best known for seizing eleven Israeli athletes as hostages at the September <a href="1972%20Summer%20Olympics">1972 Summer Olympics</a> in Munich. All the athletes and five Black September operatives died during a gun battle with the West German police in what later became known as the <a href="Munich%20massacre">Munich massacre</a>. The PFLP, founded in 1967 by <a href="George%20Habash">George Habash</a>, on September 6, 1970 <a href="aircraft%20hijacking">hijacked</a> three international passenger planes, landing two of them in Jordan and blowing up the third. Fatah leader and PLO chairman <a href="Yasser%20Arafat">Yasser Arafat</a> publicly renounced terrorism in December 1988 on behalf of the PLO, but Israel has stated that it has proof that Arafat continued to sponsor terrorism until his death in 2004.
In the 1974 <a href="Ma%27alot%20massacre">Ma'alot massacre</a> 22 Israeli high-school students, aged 14 to 16 from <a href="Safed">Safed</a> were killed by three members of the <a href="Democratic%20Front%20for%20the%20Liberation%20of%20Palestine">Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine</a>. Before reaching the school, the trio shot and killed two Arab women, a Jewish man, his pregnant wife, and their 4-year-old son, and wounded several others.
The <a href="People%27s%20Mujahedin%20of%20Iran">People's Mujahedin of Iran</a> (PMOI) or <a href="Mujahedin-e%20Khalq">Mujahedin-e Khalq</a> (founded in 1965), is a socialist Islamic group that has fought Iran's government since the <a href="w%3A1979%20Iranian%20Revolution">Khomeini revolution</a>. The group originated to oppose capitalism and what it perceived as western exploitation of Iran under <a href="Mohammad%20Reza%20Pahlavi">the Shah</a>. The group would go on to play an important role in the Shah's overthrow but was unable to capitalize on this in the following power-vacuum. The group is suspected of having a membership of between 10,000 and 30,000. The group renounced violence in 2001 but remains a proscribed terror-organization in Iran and in the United States. The EU, however, has removed the group from its terror list. The PMOI is accused of supporting other groups such as the <a href="Jundallah%20%28Iran%29">Jundallah</a>.
In 1975 <a href="Hagop%20Tarakchian">Hagop Tarakchian</a> and <a href="Hagop%20Hagopian%20%28guerilla%29">Hagop Hagopian</a>, with the help of sympathetic Palestinians, founded the <a href="Armenian%20Secret%20Army%20for%20the%20Liberation%20of%20Armenia">Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia</a> (ASALA) in <a href="Beirut">Beirut</a> during the <a href="Lebanese%20Civil%20War">Lebanese Civil War</a>. At the time Turkey was in political turmoil, and Hagopian believed that the time was right to avenge the Armenians who died during the <a href="Armenian%20genocide">Armenian genocide</a> and to force the Turkish government to cede the territory of <a href="Wilsonian%20Armenia">Wilsonian Armenia</a> to establish a nation state also incorporating the <a href="Armenian%20Soviet%20Socialist%20Republic">Armenian SSR</a>. In its <a href="Esenboga%20airport%20attack">Esenboga airport attack</a>, on 7 August 1982, two ASALA rebels opened fire on civilians in a waiting room at the <a href="Esenboga%20International%20Airport">Esenboga International Airport</a> in <a href="Ankara">Ankara</a>. Nine people died and 82 were injured. By 1986, the ASALA had virtually ceased all attacks.
The "Partiya Karkerên Kurdistan" (<a href="Kurdistan%20Workers%20Party">Kurdistan Workers Party</a> or PKK) was established in Turkey in 1978 as a Kurdish nationalist party. Founder <a href="Abdullah%20Ocalan">Abdullah Ocalan</a> was inspired by the <a href="Maoism">Maoist</a> theory of <a href="people%27s%20war">people's war</a>. At that time the group sought to create an independent Kurdish Nation State consisting of parts of south-eastern Turkey, north-eastern Iraq, north-eastern Syria and north-western Iran. In 1984 the PKK transformed itself into a paramilitary organisation and launched conventional attacks as well as bombings against Turkish governmental installations. In 1999 Turkish authorities captured Öcalan in Kenya. He was tried in Turkey and sentenced to life imprisonment. The PKK has since gone through a series of name and ideology changes. In 2004 <a href="Abdullah%20Ocalan">Abdullah Ocalan</a> announced a new ideology for the PKK from prison called <a href="Jineology">Jineology</a> (the Science and history of women) radically diverging from its Marxist-Leninist roots. The ideology proposed a system of <a href="Democratic%20confederalism">Democratic confederalism</a> without central Nation State government. Women have played a very important role in the development of this ideology during the 1990s and have also formed an army called the <a href="YPJ">YPJ</a> (Women's Protection Units) to defend the new society. Since then, the European Court Of Justice has annulled the decision to class the PKK as a terrorist group on grounds that "sufficient arguments were not presented" .
Europe.
Founded in 1959 and functioning until 2018, the <a href="Euskadi%20Ta%20Askatasuna">Euskadi Ta Askatasuna</a> (or ETA - <a href="Basque%20language">Basque</a> for "Basque Homeland and Freedom", pronounced ) was an armed <a href="Basque%20nationalist">Basque nationalist</a> separatist organization. Formed in response to the suppression of the Basque language and culture under the régime of General <a href="Francisco%20Franco">Francisco Franco</a> (in power 1939–1975) in Spain, ETA evolved from an advocacy group for traditional Basque culture into an armed <a href="Marxism">Marxist</a> group demanding Basque independence. Many ETA victims were government officials; the group's first known victim, a police chief, died in 1968. In 1973 ETA operatives killed Franco's apparent successor, Admiral <a href="Luis%20Carrero%20Blanco">Luis Carrero Blanco</a>, by planting an underground bomb under his habitual parking-spot outside a Madrid church. In 1995 an ETA car-bomb nearly killed <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Mar%C3%ADa%20Aznar">José María Aznar</a>, then the leader of the conservative Popular Party, and in the same year investigators disrupted a plot to assassinate King <a href="Juan%20Carlos%20I%20of%20Spain">Juan Carlos</a>. Efforts by Spanish governments to negotiate with the ETA failed, and in 2003 the Spanish Supreme Court banned the Batasuna political party, which was determined to be the political arm of ETA.
The <a href="Provisional%20Irish%20Republican%20Army">Provisional Irish Republican Army</a> (IRA) was an <a href="Irish%20nationalism">Irish nationalist</a> movement founded in December 1969 when several militants, including <a href="Se%C3%A1n%20Mac%20St%C3%ADof%C3%A1in">Seán Mac Stíofáin</a>, broke off from the <a href="Official%20IRA">Official IRA</a> and formed a new organization. Led by Mac Stíofáin in the early 1970s and by a group around <a href="Gerry%20Adams">Gerry Adams</a> since the late 1970s, the Provisional IRA sought to bring about an all-island Irish state. Between 1969 and 1997, during a period known as <a href="the%20Troubles">the Troubles</a>, the group conducted an <a href="Provisional%20IRA%20campaign%201969-1997">armed campaign</a>, including bombings, gun attacks, assassinations and even a <a href="Downing%20Street%20mortar%20attack">mortar attack on 10 Downing Street</a>. On July 21, 1972, in an attack later dubbed <a href="Bloody%20Friday%20%281972%29">Bloody Friday</a>, the group set off twenty-two bombs, killing nine and injuring 130. On July 28, 2005, the Provisional IRA Army Council announced an end to its armed campaign. The IRA is believed to have been a major exporter of arms and to have provided military training to groups such as the <a href="FARC">FARC</a> in Colombia and the PLO. In the case of the latter there has been a long-standing solidarity movement, as evidenced by many murals around <a href="Belfast">Belfast</a>.
The <a href="Red%20Army%20Faction">Red Army Faction</a> (RAF) was a <a href="New%20Left">New Left</a> group founded in 1968 by <a href="Andreas%20Baader">Andreas Baader</a> and <a href="Ulrike%20Meinhof">Ulrike Meinhof</a> in West Germany. Inspired by <a href="Che%20Guevara">Che Guevara</a>, <a href="Maoism">Maoist</a> socialism, and the <a href="Vietcong">Vietcong</a>, the group sought to raise awareness of the Vietnamese and Palestinian independence movements through kidnappings, taking embassies hostage, bank robberies, assassinations, bombings, and attacks on U.S. air bases. The group became arguably best known for 1977's "<a href="German%20Autumn">German Autumn</a>". The buildup leading to German Autumn began on April 7, when the RAF shot Federal Prosecutor <a href="Siegfried%20Buback">Siegfried Buback</a>. On July 30, it shot <a href="J%C3%BCrgen%20Ponto">Jürgen Ponto</a>, then head of the Dresdner Bank, in a failed kidnapping attempt; on September 5, the group kidnapped <a href="Hanns%20Martin%20Schleyer">Hanns Martin Schleyer</a> (a former SS officer and an important West German industrialist), executing him on October 19. The hijacking of the <a href="Lufthansa">Lufthansa</a> jetliner <a href="Lufthansa%20Flight%20181">"Landshut"</a> in October 1977 by the <a href="Popular%20Front%20for%20the%20Liberation%20of%20Palestine">PFLP</a>, a Palestinian group, is also considered to be part of German Autumn.
The <a href="Red%20Brigades">Red Brigades</a>, a New Left group founded by <a href="Renato%20Curcio">Renato Curcio</a> and <a href="Alberto%20Franceschini">Alberto Franceschini</a> in 1970 and based in Italy, sought to create a revolutionary state. The group carried out a series of bombings and kidnappings until the arrests of Curcio and Franceschini in the mid-1970s. Their successor as <a href="leader">leader</a>, <a href="Mario%20Moretti">Mario Moretti</a>, led the group toward more militarized and violent actions, including the kidnapping of former <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Italy">Italian Prime Minister</a> <a href="Aldo%20Moro">Aldo Moro</a> on March 16, 1978. Moro was killed 56 days later. This led to an all-out assault on the group by Italian law-enforcement and security forces and condemnation from Italian left-wing radicals and even from imprisoned ex-leaders of the Brigades. The group lost most of its social support and public opinion turned strongly against it. In 1984 the group split, the majority faction becoming the Communist Combatant Party (Red Brigades-PCC) and the minority faction reconstituting itself as the Union of Combatant Communists (Red Brigades-UCC). Members of these groups carried out a handful of assassinations before almost all were arrested in 1989.
The Americas.
The "<a href="Front%20de%20lib%C3%A9ration%20du%20Qu%C3%A9bec">Front de libération du Québec</a>" (FLQ) was a Marxist nationalist group that sought to create an independent, socialist <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>. <a href="Georges%20Schoeters">Georges Schoeters</a> founded the group in 1963 and was inspired by <a href="Che%20Guevara">Che Guevara</a> and Algeria's FLN. The group was accused of bombings, kidnappings, and assassinations of politicians, soldiers, and civilians. On October 5, 1970, the FLQ kidnapped <a href="James%20Richard%20Cross">James Richard Cross</a>, the British Trade Commissioner, and on October 10, the Minister of Labor and Vice-Premier of Quebec, <a href="Pierre%20Laporte">Pierre Laporte</a>. Laporte was killed a week later. After these events support for violence in order to attain Quebec's independence declined, and support increased for the Parti Québécois, which took power in Quebec in 1976.
In Colombia <a href="Narcoterrorism">several paramilitary and guerrilla groups</a> formed during the 1960s and afterwards. In 1983, President <a href="Fernando%20Bela%C3%BAnde%20Terry">Fernando Belaúnde Terry</a> of Peru described armed attacks on his nation's anti-narcotics police as "<a href="narcoterrorism">narcoterrorism</a>", i.e., which refers to "violence waged by drug producers to extract <a href="concession%20%28politics%29">political concessions</a> from the government." <a href="Pablo%20Escobar">Pablo Escobar</a>'s ruthless violence in his dealings with the Colombian and Peruvian governments has been probably two of the best known and best documented examples of narcoterrorism. Paramilitary groups associated with narcoterrorism include the <a href="National%20Liberation%20Army%20%28Colombia%29">Ejército de Liberación Nacional</a> (ELN), the <a href="Revolutionary%20Armed%20Forces%20of%20Colombia">Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia</a> (FARC), and the <a href="United%20Self-Defense%20Forces%20of%20Colombia">Autodefensas Unidas de Colombia</a> (AUC). While the ELN and FARC were originally left wing revolutionary groups and the AUC was originally a right-wing paramilitary, all have conducted numerous attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure and engaged in the drug trade. The U.S. and some European governments consider them terrorist organizations.
The <a href="Jewish%20Defense%20League">Jewish Defense League</a> (JDL) was founded in 1969 by Rabbi <a href="Meir%20Kahane">Meir Kahane</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, with its declared purpose being the protection of Jews from harassment and <a href="antisemitism">antisemitism</a>. <a href="Federal%20Bureau%20of%20Investigation">Federal Bureau of Investigation</a> statistics state that, from 1980 to 1985, 15 attacks which the FBI classified as acts of terrorism were attempted in the U.S. by members of the JDL. The <a href="Terrorism%20Knowledge%20Base">National Consortium for the Study of Terror and Responses to Terrorism</a> states that, during the JDL's first two decades of activity, it was an "active terrorist organization.". Kahane later founded the far-right Israeli political party <a href="Kach%20and%20Kahane%20Chai">Kach</a>, which was banned from elections in Israel on the ground of racism. The JDL's present-day website condemns all forms of terrorism.
The "<a href="Fuerzas%20Armadas%20de%20Liberaci%C3%B3n%20Nacional%20Puertorrique%C3%B1a">Fuerzas Armadas de Liberación Nacional</a>" (FALN, "Armed Forces of National Liberation") is a nationalist group founded in Puerto Rico in 1974. Over the decade that followed the group used bombings and targeted killings of civilians and police in pursuit of an independent Puerto Rico. The FALN in 1975 took responsibility for four nearly simultaneous bombings in New York City. The United States <a href="Federal%20Bureau%20of%20Investigation">Federal Bureau of Investigation</a> (FBI) has classified the FALN as a terrorist organization.
The <a href="Weather%20Underground">Weather Underground</a> (a.k.a. the Weathermen) began as a militant faction of the leftist <a href="Students%20for%20a%20Democratic%20Society%20%281960%20organization%29">Students for a Democratic Society</a> (SDS) organization, and in 1969 took over the organization. Weathermen leaders, inspired by China's <a href="Maoism">Maoists</a>, the <a href="Black%20Panthers">Black Panthers</a>, and the <a href="May%201968%20in%20France">1968 student revolts in France</a>, sought to raise awareness of its revolutionary anti-capitalist and anti-<a href="Vietnam%20War">Vietnam War</a> platform by destroying symbols of government power. From 1969 to 1974 the Weathermen bombed corporate offices, police stations, and <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington</a> government sites such as the <a href="The%20Pentagon">Pentagon</a>. After the end of the Vietnam War in 1975, most of the group disbanded.
Asia.
The <a href="Japanese%20Red%20Army">Japanese Red Army</a> was founded by <a href="Fusako%20Shigenobu">Fusako Shigenobu</a> in Japan in 1971 and attempted to overthrow the Japanese government and start a world revolution. Allied with the <a href="Popular%20Front%20for%20the%20Liberation%20of%20Palestine">Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine</a> (PFLP), the group committed assassinations, hijacked a commercial Japanese aircraft, and sabotaged a Shell oil refinery in Singapore. On May 30, 1972, <a href="K%C5%8Dz%C5%8D%20Okamoto">Kōzō Okamoto</a> and other group members launched a machine gun and grenade attack at Israel's Lod Airport in Tel Aviv, killing 26 people and injuring 80 others. Two of the three attackers then killed themselves with grenades.
Founded in 1976, the <a href="Liberation%20Tigers%20of%20Tamil%20Eelam">Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam</a>, (also called "LTTE" or Tamil Tigers) was a militant <a href="Tamil%20people">Tamil</a> nationalist political and paramilitary organization based in northern Sri Lanka. From its founding by <a href="Velupillai%20Prabhakaran">Velupillai Prabhakaran</a>, it waged a <a href="secessionist">secessionist</a> resistance campaign that sought to create an independent Tamil state in the northern and eastern regions of Sri Lanka. The conflict originated in measures the majority <a href="Sinhalese%20people">Sinhalese</a> took that were perceived as attempts to marginalize the Tamil minority. The resistance campaign evolved into the <a href="Sri%20Lankan%20Civil%20War">Sri Lankan Civil War</a>, one of the longest-running armed conflicts in Asia. The group carried out many bombings, including an April 21, 1987, car bomb attack at a <a href="Colombo">Colombo</a> bus terminal that killed 110 people. In 2009 the Sri Lankan military launched a major military offensive against the secessionist movement and claimed that it had effectively destroyed the LTTE.
Africa.
In Kenya, because of the seeming ongoing failure of the Kenyan African Union to obtain political reforms from the British government through peaceful means, radical activists within the KAU set up a splinter group and organised a more militant kind of nationalism. By 1952 The Mau Mau consisted of Kikuyu fighters, along with some Embu and Meru recruits. The Mau Mau carried out attacks on political opponents, loyalist villages, raiding white farms and destroying livestock. The colonial administration declared a state of emergency and British forces were sent to Kenya. The majority of fighting was between loyalist and Mau Mau Kikuyu, so many scholars today now consider it a Kikuyu civil war. The Kenyan Government considers the <a href="Mau%20Mau%20Uprising">Mau Mau Uprising</a> a key step towards Kenya's eventual independence in the 1960s. Many Mau Mau members provided reports of torture and abuse suffered by them to foreign journalists, though the British forces did have strict orders not to mistreat Mau Mau terrorists.

Asia.
<a href="Aum%20Shinrikyo">Aum Shinrikyo</a>, now known as Aleph, was a Japanese <a href="New%20religious%20movement">religious group</a> founded by <a href="Shoko%20Asahara">Shoko Asahara</a> in 1984 as a yogic meditation group.
